section.title: Definition
section.para: Deployment elements, test-install, test-update and publish, provide settings for the corresponding deployment modules. These deployment modules complete the following tasks:

itemizedlist.listitem: Publish a solution repository to a file system location on the build machine. See .

Assemble files and information related to installing and updating client machines using the solution repository. Make assembled information available to other CentOS Studio modules as well as to sub-components of the individual deployment module. See , , , , and .

listitem.para: Optionally, exceute one or more user-provided deployment script. See , , , , and .

section.para: CentOS Studio executes deployment scripts according to the following logic:

itemizedlist.listitem: First, CentOS Studio performs a number of tests to determine if system install or reinstall is necessary. See .

If the triggers indicate that an install/reinstall is necessary, CentOS Studio executes scripts in this order:
delete-script install-script activate-script verify-install-script post-script

Otherwise, CentOS Studio executes these scripts:
update-script post-script
If any script is not provided, it is skipped silently.

section.para: Deployment scripts can be written in any shell scripting language.

By default, CentOS Studio executes the activate-script, delete-script and install-script on the build machine and the verify-install-script, update-script and post-script on a client machine specified using the @hostname attribute. Script execution on client machines is accomplished using Secure Shell (SSH).
CentOS Studio supports password authentication for SSH connections. It does not support public key or host-based authentication.
SSH execution can be disabled for any script, allowing users to provide support for remote connections and authentication using any method desired.
See the CentOS Studio User Manual for information on configuring build and client machines for SSH connectivity.

@interface: The network interface name, e.g. "eth1", from which to obtain the $ipaddress of the solution's update repository. This attribute only has an effect if remote-url/@fqdn is FALSE. By default, CentOS Studio uses the first active, non-loopback network interface.

@fqdn: BOOLEAN that determines whether CentOS Studio uses the build machine's fully qualified domain name or IP address in the automatically-computed remote url. The default value for this attribute is FALSE.

A TEXT value specifying boot environment variables, or kernel boot arguments, for use during client machine installation. Provided as a local macro, %{boot-options}, for use within deployment element content, primarly the install-script. Also used by CentOS Studio during the creation of iso images.
In the CentOS Studio context, the boot-option element is commonly used to automate system installation, in combination with a kickstart file.

The boot-options element's text value should be a space-separated list of kernel arguments. To enable automated system installations, two options are required: lang and keymap. These control the language displayed during the installation process. They take ISO language and keymap values. See below for examples. Use the command locale -a to view a list of available language locales.
For more information on available boot options, see the chapter on Boot Options in the Red Hat Enterprise Linux Installation Guide

When creating iso images, including the boot.iso image, CentOS Studio appends provided options to each "append" line in the syslinux configuration file. In addition, iso images are automatically configured to use a kickstart, if provided.
Boot-options is an optional element. The default value is an empty string.

The kickstart element specifies the text of a kickstart file. CentOS Studio makes the kickstart available as a file named named ks.cfg included in the os folder of the solution repository, e.g. http://server.company.com/solutions/samba-server-5-i386/os/ks.cfg. It also includes the kickstart in all ISO images including boot.iso.

The TEXT of a script used to activate one or more machines, or determine if one or more machines are active. The script must return a non-zero exit status if activation fails.
Activate-script is optional for the publish element, and required for test-install and test-update.

Example - This example uses a python script to attempt a connection to a virtual machine on the build machine. The virtual machine is identified using the %{hostname} macro. If the virtual machine does not exist or cannot be activated, the script returns an exit status of '1'.
The TEXT of a script used to delete, remove or destroy one more machines in preparation for a clean installation. The script must return a non-zero exit status if machine deletion fails.
Delete-script is optional for the publish element, and required for the test-install and test-update elements.

Example - In this example, a bash script is used to destroy and undefine a virtual machine specified using the %{hostname} macro. The command set -e is used at the beginning of the script to indicate that if any command in the script fails, the script should return a non-zero exit status. Typically bash scripts return the exit status of the last command executed in the script.
The TEXT of a script used to perform system installation to one or more machines. The script must return a non-zero exit status if installation fails.
The install-script is commonly used with the %{hostname} and %{url} macros.
Install-script is optional for the publish element, and required for the test-install and test-update elements.
Example - This example uses three elements boot-options, kickstart and install-script.
The boot-options element specifies language settings for the installer. These are required for automated system installation.
The kickstart element provides settings for the client machine. A kickstart is also required for automated system installation.

The install-script element provides a a bash script which completes the actual machine installation. In this case, the script executes the virt-install command to create a new virtual machine. The script uses the %{hostname} macro to specify a name for the virtual machine, as well as the filename for the machine's image. It uses the %{url} macro to specify the location for the installation files, as well as for the kickstart file. Finally, it uses the boot-options macro to specify the display language for the installer.
The set -e command has not been used in this script as it was in the example. In this case it is unnecessary because the script contains only a single command, virt-install.
The TEXT of a script that verifies system installation on one or more client machines. The script must return a non-zero exit status if install verification fails.

The script can perform any desired actions to verify system installation. One recommended action is to scan the /root/install.log file for "scriptlet failed" errors. Scriptlet failed errors identify issues in which RPM packages, quite possibly the config-rpm (defined in the element), failed to install as expected. See the examples section below for a script that scans for and reports "scriptlet failed" errors. See the CentOS Studio User Manual for information on troubleshooting "scriptlet failed" errors related to the config-rpm.
Verify-install-script is optional for the publish element and required for the test-install and test-update elements.

Example - In this example the verify-install-script element provides a bash script which uses the grep to scan for scriptlet failed errors in the install.log. If errors are found, the script returns an exit status of '1', indicating that verification failed.
Updates an installed client, typically by executing the yum sync or yum update commands, followed by performing update verification as desired.

The update-script may also be used for post processing after client updates. For example, the update-script may be used to test the running system kernel and restart the machine if a new kernel version has been installed, as is shown in the example update-script below. Note that while post processing actions such as these could be performed in either the update-script or the post-script, the former is preferable since the latter is executed after both installation and updates.

Update-script is optional for the publish element, absent from the test-install element, and required for the test-update element.
Example - In the following example, a bash script is provided that updates the client using the yum sync command. Thereafter, the script tests for a new kernel, and restarts the client if one is found. The set -e is used to halt processing and return a non-zero exit status if an error occurs at any point within the script.
Provides a script that runs following all other scripts.

For the publish event, this script is useful for copying published solution repositories to remote download servers. It can also be used to integrate solutions with enterprise systems management systems, for example to sync solution repository content with software channels in Red Hat Network or Spacewalk. In scenarios such as these, it is necessary to set the @ssh attribute to a false value.

For the test-install and test-update events, the post-script is useful for activities such as completing testing that should run after either install or update, or for powering down test machines between runs.
Post-script is an optional element.
Examples - In this example, the post-script is a simple bash script with a single command to shut down the client machine.
